title: Republican sheriff nominee shares photo of himself in BLACKFACE from 2009 in campaign video
text:
A South Carolina policeman running for sheriff announced his campaign in a video that included a photo of him in blackface during a law enforcement Halloween costume party.

Craig Stivender is running as the 'Republican Nomination for Sheriff of Colleton County' and shared the alarming photo in a bid to open his campaign with 'transparency.'

About halfway through his campaign video, Stivender explains that he decided to dress up as 'ruthless drug kingpin' Demetrius 'Big Meech' Flenory during a police Halloween party in 2010.

Scroll down for video

Craig Stivender is running as the 'Republican Nomination for Sheriff of Colleton County' and shared the alarming photo in a bid to open his campaign with 'transparency'

About halfway through his campaign video, Stivender explains that he decided to dress up as 'ruthless drug kingpin' Demetrius 'Big Meech' Flenory during a police Halloween party in 2010

Flenory was sentenced to 30 years in prison in 2008 for his role in the Black Mafia Family drug trafficking ring.

The photo shows Stivender dressed in an aqua-blue shirt while sporting a gold chain. He's hugged up with a black woman.

Flenory was sentenced to 30 years in prison in 2008 for his role in the Black Mafia Family drug trafficking ring

Stivender claimed that he chose to dress up as Flannery in a bid to 'disparage a criminal' before acknowledging that 'that was a different time.'

He continued: 'Today we understand that type of costume is troubling to many. To those who may be upset, I understand your disappointment but I value honesty so I am opening my campaign with transparency.'

Since posting the video, Stivender has thanked supporters who have shared how touched they were by the video. He's also spent a lot of time telling his naysayers to pick up Bibles.

'How did you reach the age of 35 without knowing blackface was racist? I think most of us learned it by 2nd grade,' stated one user. 'Heck, based on your accusation that people are just too sensitive about it today, I'm not even sure you really understand it today.

'Please go find a middle or high school student and ask to borrow their US history book. No one running for sheriff should be that ignorant.

Stivender said that he wouldn't wear blackface today as 'people are very easily offended'

The sentiment was shared by other users who pointed out that Colleton County has a African American population of nearly 40percent.

A user said: '"That was a different time." How many outtakes before you could say that with a straight face? IT WAS 2009. And you were a cop at the time, mocking the people you supposedly serve. GTFOH'

In an interview with NPR, Stivender described that the party took place at the current sheriff's home and was shared on social media.

Many took the police officer to task for wearing black face

He claimed to have shared the photo in an effort to get ahead of the curve, noting that it is popular for people to find dirt on political-hopefuls.

'If I dressed up in blackface today, it would definitely be an issue because we know today that people are very easily offended over things that were maybe not so much ten years ago,' he said.

Stivender told the DailyMail.com that he stood behind his campaign video and statements made.

The father-of-three has been in law enforcement for 15 years, starting at the Cottageville Police Department before moving on to become a deputy at the Colleton County Sheriff's Office.

He is currently working at the Walterboro Police Department and has been with the department since 2010.
